Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A pendulum consists of a string of length <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math> attached to a small sphere of mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>. A horizontal peg is placed a distance <math alttext="L over 2" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></math> directly below the point where the string is attached to the ceiling. The sphere is pulled up and to the left, and the string bends at the peg until the lower half of the string is horizontal, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The sphere is released from rest and allowed to swing through Point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.
content.question:
(a) Figure <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"> <mn>3</mn> </math> shows an incomplete energy bar chart for the sphere – Earth system at the time the sphere is released from rest. Figure <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math> shows an incomplete energy bar chart for the sphere – Earth system when the sphere passes through Point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>.

i. Draw complete energy bar charts, showing the potential energy of the sphere – Earth system <math alttext="U sub g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>g</mi></msub></mstyle></math> and the kinetic energy <math alttext="K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>K</mi></mstyle></math> of the sphere at the moment the sphere is released from rest and as it passes through Point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> in figures <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> and <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>, respectively.

Positive energy values are above the zero – energy line (“<math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn></math>”), and negative energy values are below the zero – energy line.

Shaded regions should start at the dashed line representing the zero – energy line.

Represent any energy that is equal to zero with a distinct line on the zero – energy line.

The relative height of each bar should reflect the magnitude of the energy.

ii. Derive an equation for the speed of the sphere as it passes through Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>P</mtext></mstyle></math> in terms of <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math> and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference information.

The sphere momentarily comes to rest at Point <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Q</mtext></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn></math>.

iii. Calculate the numerical value of the angle <math alttext="theta sub maximum" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></mstyle></math> the string makes with the vertical at the moment the sphere instantaneously comes to rest at Point <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi></math>.

The peg that causes the string to bend in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> can be moved up (closer to the ceiling) or down (further from the ceiling) along the vertical line that goes through the point where the string is attached to the ceiling. The experiment is repeated with the sphere pulled up and to the left so that the string bends at the peg until the lower portion of the string is horizontal. The sphere is then released from rest.

(b) Indicate whether the peg should be moved up or down in order to increase the angle <math alttext="theta sub maximum" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></mstyle></math> the string makes with the vertical when the sphere momentarily comes to rest on the right side.

Justify your response.
